review:
Alright, let’s cut through the noise and get to the alpha. Zazelenimo is a Web3 dApp targeting participatory budgeting for urban greening, built open-source, leveraging Ethereum, quadratic funding, and onboarding both citizens and municipalities. The project’s OSS-first approach, integration with real-world institutions (City of Split), and focus on quadratic funding for public goods are all strong signals for systemic impact and scalability.

From a maximization lens, Zazelenimo’s model is designed to scale: it’s not just a local hackathon project, but a blueprint for how cities can use OSS and Web3 rails to disrupt legacy, closed-source civic tech. The quadratic funding mechanism is a proven, high-utility approach for maximizing community-driven resource allocation (see Gitcoin’s own research on QF). The onboarding of non-crypto-native users via passkey wallets and fiat onramps is a major plus for adoption and impact.

However, the application is a bit light on hard metrics for projected user growth, adoption outside Split, and technical details on how the platform will be maintained and scaled. There’s also a lack of clarity on the open-source governance model—who’s steering the ship long-term? The legal and compliance roadmap is mentioned, but not detailed. For a project aiming for systemic change, these are non-trivial gaps.

The project’s focus on government partnerships is a double-edged sword: it’s a high-leverage move if it works, but could bottleneck scale if adoption is slow or bureaucratic. The application would benefit from a more explicit plan for scaling beyond the initial pilot, including metrics, partnerships, and a roadmap for OSS community engagement.

Bottom line: Zazelenimo is a high-potential, OSS-native civic dApp with real-world traction and a disruptive model. But to hit max utility and scale, it needs to tighten up its growth, governance, and sustainability story. Let’s see some hard numbers, a clear OSS roadmap, and a plan to go global, not just local.

Citations: Gitcoin QF research, OSS adoption in public sector (see "Open Source in Government: Benefits and Challenges," European Commission, 2022), and best practices for OSS governance (see "The Open Source Way").

strengths.title: OSS-Native, Public Good Focus
strengths.description: Built entirely open-source, leverages Ethereum, Cometh Connect, and Allo Protocol. Directly targets public goods funding and civic engagement—max utility for the greatest number.

strengths.title: Quadratic Funding Mechanism
strengths.description: Implements QF for democratic, high-impact resource allocation. Proven model for maximizing community-driven outcomes.

strengths.title: Real-World Institutional Integration
strengths.description: Partnership with City of Split demonstrates practical, systemic impact and potential for broader government adoption.

strengths.title: User-Centric Onboarding
strengths.description: Passkey-based wallets and fiat onramps lower the barrier for non-crypto users, boosting adoption and impact.

weaknesses.title: Lack of Hard Growth Metrics
weaknesses.description: No concrete projections for user growth, adoption outside Split, or platform scaling. Impact potential is high, but numbers are missing.

weaknesses.title: Unclear OSS Governance Model
weaknesses.description: No details on long-term open-source governance, community stewardship, or decision-making processes.

weaknesses.title: Legal and Compliance Ambiguity
weaknesses.description: Mentions legal setup, but lacks specifics on compliance, especially for multi-jurisdictional scaling.

weaknesses.title: Scaling Plan Needs Work
weaknesses.description: Heavy reliance on government partnerships could bottleneck scale. No clear roadmap for expansion beyond the initial pilot.

changes.title: Add Concrete Growth Metrics
changes.description: Provide projections for user growth, city expansion, and platform adoption over 1-3 years. Show the numbers—let’s see the scale potential.

changes.title: Detail OSS Governance and Stewardship
changes.description: Outline the open-source governance model: who maintains the code, how decisions are made, and how the community can contribute long-term.

changes.title: Clarify Legal and Compliance Roadmap
changes.description: Give specifics on legal frameworks, compliance strategies, and how you’ll handle cross-border regulatory issues as you scale.

changes.title: Expand on Scaling and Replication Strategy
changes.description: Present a clear, actionable plan for scaling beyond Split: partnerships, OSS community engagement, and a roadmap for onboarding new cities.
